clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Fosfomycin in Prosthetic Joint Infection
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Fosfomycin in Prosthetic Joint Infection (PJI) Caused by Staphylococci, Streptococci, Enterococci and Gram-negative Bacilli, Including Mixed Infections and Culture Negative PJI's ("PROOF-Study")

brief_summary.textblock: The PROOF Study is an open prospective interventional non-randomized study which aim is to determine the outcome / effect and safety of fosfomycin in patients with hip, knee or shoulder PJI.

detailed_description.textblock: To confirm a non-inferior effect and the safety of the investigated antimicrobial fosfomycin regimen in PJI of the hip, knee or shoulder against an assumed 80% effect (PJI-free proportion within one year for standard antibiotics aside fosfomycin), following a standardized surgical therapy involving retention, one-stage exchange or two-stage exchange (with short or long interval).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: In this open prospective interventional clinical study patients with hip, knee or shoulder PJI (as defined below) caused by fosfomycin-susceptible staphylococci, streptococci, enterococci or gram-negative bacilli will be included. After inclusion and PJI-surgery, intravenous fosfomycin will be given 5 g every 8 hours for 1, 2, 3-or -4 weeks according to the pathogen and surgery procedure and generally as a part of the antibiotic combination therapy of the treatment algorithm. This Treatment is followed by oral antibiotics for a total of 3 months.

primary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients free of PJI relapse (i.e. infection cure rate) within 1 year after inclusion. Relapse is defined as new PJI diagnosis more than 4 weeks after the last surgical intervention of the initial 12 week treatment period.

secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients free of Prosthetic Joint-Infection relapse (infection cure rate) within 2 years after inclusion
Proportion of patients with revision (surgical intervention with or without prosthesis removal >4 weeks after last surgical intervention of the initial 12 week treatment period)

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with revision due to hematogenous versus non-hematogenous infection
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with revision due to hematogenous (acute onset with duration of symptoms <3 weeks and onset of symptoms is >3 months after last surgery) versus non-hematogenous infection

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with unscheduled early revisions
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with unscheduled early revisions (<4 weeks after last scheduled surgical intervention - deep (= bone/joint) revision versus superficial (= skin-soft tissue) revision)

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with aseptic revision
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with aseptic revision

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with implant failure
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with implant failure (any functionally affected or pain producing implant, clinically relevant abnormal laboratory test result indicating PJI, or presence of radiological signs of loosening, according to the investigator (Yes/No))

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with treatment failure
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with treatment failure (insufficient primary therapy or PJI relapse)

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients with initially sufficient versus insufficient primary therapy
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with initially sufficient versus insufficient primary therapy (defined by the judgement of the investigator, based on combined clinical, laboratory, microbiological and radiological criteria, e.g. clear reduction of wound secretion)
Development and changes vs baseline of specific functional joint scores
EQ5D5L (in particular for 1 year follow up)

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety and tolerability of fosfomycin (frequency of adverse events)
secondary_outcome.description: Safety and tolerability of fosfomycin will be evaluated by measuring the frequency of adverse events, including potential side effects
